Impact / Alignment Note:
This porposal ask for funding of a very decisive and 'official' role within the CATALYST CIRCLE. 

This role has started out on voluntary (unpaid) basis, but requires now substantial work-effort of about 30 hours a month and needs to be funded (it is all about documenting and maintaining the work of the CATALYST CIRCLE in the correponding GitHub repository). 

According to my personal profesional experience, these type of work is absolutely essential for collaborative organizations - therefore my full support.
Feasibility Note:
The proposer, Stephen Whitenstall, has 30 years experience in organizing academic, community and business projects and is deeply engaged within CATALYST CIRCLE and SWARM. 

Major elements of the proposal already exist and are heavily used. The proposal is mainly about the ongoing work of documenting and sharing the work of the CATALYST CIRCLE. 

What I can judge, usage and adoption are therefore highly secured - therefore my full support.
Auditability Note:
The proposer has outlined the costs, roadmap and major elements of the work behind this proposal. All is based on already happening (currently voluntary) activities, which need to be fairly funded now. 

The applied rates and the asked funding apprears very reasonable to me - therefore also my full support for this part of the proposal.

Impact / Alignment Note: Yes. It may not be straightforward to everyone how documentation and more generally, information contribute to decision making, nevertheless, in time it should become clearer to Cardano supporters that documentation and information are fundamental for decision making in technological innovation, software development, and blockchain governance. This project does a very efficient job, founded by actual work done, in demonstrating how documentation for oversight can be achieved. Outside of the scope of the current proposal, I would recommend that the proponent considers how oversight will relate in the future to implementation (i.e.: sanctioning corrupt or inefficient behavior). The reason for this suggestion is that in the long run, oversight without sanctions/control would eventually become useless. Thank you for your proposal and good luck.
Feasibility Note: Yes. The proponent provides us with confidence to support the project by having already demonstrated it without the precious economic undersigning. This is an example of innovation through execution and iteration.
Auditability Note: Yes. The proposal provides not only the information necessary to audit it but also the tools (links) to do so. In addition, the proponent has demonstrated availability and responsiveness to the Catalyst community. I highly recommend that if the proposal is funded, the proponent pay great attention to the automation and future decentralization of the oversight tools. It will be highly desirable that in the future, the tools developed here for project oversight can be transferred to other community members, to other projects, to future generations, and to decentralized communities. To achieve this, it seems desirable that the processes of documenting activities, publishing and disseminating will be as automated as possible and independent from individual human skills and dispositions (e.g.: going from automatic note-taking i.e.: 'subtitles generation', to social media posting).

Impact / Alignment Note: The ongoing work outlined in the proposal is to the benefit of the Cardano ecosystem and addresses the challenge effectively.
Feasibility Note: The proposer has a track record of delivering value. The plan is detailed with a reasonable and understandable budget. It is highly likely that the proposal will be implemented successfully.
Auditability Note: The roadmap acts as sufficient metrics which can be audited by the community.

Impact / Alignment Note:
The proposal fits well in challenge settings (A sense of community and conversations), and the project is having a vibrating impact on Cardano community already. 

The key metrics and goals of the proposal align with the outlined challenge settings and the proposal is able to address future challenges.
Feasibility Note:
An ongoing viable project needs funding for a 3 months maintenance period and the working plan is very well articulated. 

The budget is realistically outlined and broken down into identifiable items and is reasonable to achieve the set goal. 

No risk is associated with the solution, but for that type of activity and for its necessary timeframe it is unlikely that something (impactful) may occur to alter the state of this phase of project.
Auditability Note:
It is highly likely that the proposal will succed as is well articulated as a working plan, has its roadmap defined with milestones and a time horizon for achievement, and the given experience of the proposer. 

Metrics/KPIs that define the success of the proposal are set.

Impact / Alignment Note: Allows for independent oversight of Catalyst Circle + active site that documents & tracks the activities of the Catalyst Circle
Feasibility Note: Stephen Whitenstall has 30 years' experience in organizing academic, community and business projects. He develops, maintains documentation and provides technical project management support for Catalyst Swarm. Clear budget, marketing, and roadmap.
Auditability Note: weekly breakdowns, as week as a clear outline

Impact / Alignment Note:
The problem and solution are reasonable and within the scope of the challenge. 

Catalyst-Swarm-Genesis GitBook is a repository of important information about Catalyst Swarm and Catalyst. The maintenance and curation of live sessions and information about Catalyst allows for a channel of aggregation and redirection of the community, important aspects to educate and inform the community, which consequently helps to maintain cohesion and mitigate information fragmentation, providing a channel where people can learn about Catalyst and know where to look for more information. Gitbook maintenance also allows for asynchronous communication, enabling the community to access content from previous sessions in the future. 

No metrics/KPIs related to the material to be cataloged were presented, which I consider important for impact assessment. I would recommend establishing some targets for the amount of material to be archived.
Feasibility Note:
The proposer has been carrying out the work voluntarily for a few months and by looking at the Gitbook it is possible to check the quality of the work developed. There are details about the proposer's qualifications and experience (with sources to check) indicating ability to execute the proposal. 

There is a reasonable and adequate plan for maintaining the repository for a period of 3 months. A budget breakdown was presented and the values defined are reasonable.
Auditability Note:
There is clarity in the problem, solution and their relationship to the challenge. 

The roadmap has a temporary line of 12 months, and the fundind will be allocated to the next three months of maintenance, the proposer will look for alternative funding on the following months. 

The cataloged material is public, so it is easy to check what is being carried out. Metrics/KPIs were not established that would allow the proposal to be audited in an objective way. I would recommend including targets for the files/content to be added to Gitbook.

Impact / Alignment Note:
The problem and solution presented are reasonable and within the scope of the challenge. 

Distributed decision making was one of the reasons that Catalyst Circle was created and is composed of 7 members from different sectors of the community. These members are representatives of large groups and different interests. Maintaining coordination across such a large community and with such broad and diverse interests makes the Catalyst Circle role essential to Cardano's governance. This proposal seeks to document, monitor and communicate information from the Catalyst Circle, so I see huge potential impact for the challenge. 

It was established that the proposal will maintain documentation, monitoring and communication of information for 6 months, and an estimate of 27 hours per month was established for the fulfillment of these activities. These goals indicate a positive and evident impact on the challenge. 

I believe the inclusion of some goals/KPIs could more clearly demonstrate the potential impact of the proposal.
Feasibility Note:
The proposer described extensive professional experience in organizing academic, community and business projects and inserted sources for verification/attestation. 

There is a link to Gitbook where it is possible to check the work already performed voluntarily by the proposer for a few months. 

The proposal presents a comprehensive and well-structured plan, reasonable timeline There is a reasonable budget breakdown associated with hourly load x hourly rate. 

The information presented indicates total feasibility conditions for the execution and the fact that the proposer has been developing the work for several weeks on a voluntary basis is an excellent indicator.
Auditability Note:
There is clarity on the problem, solution and alignment with the challenge. 
The fact that the development of the project is open source and maintains gitbook helps a lot in the audit process. A roadmap with goals was presented. I recommend adding metrics/KPIs for easy auditing.

Impact / Alignment Note: The problem and solution description is within the scope of the challenge. The proposal is fully aligned with the challenge and has great potential to improve the documenting, tracking & communicating the activities, discussions and decisions of Catalyst Circle thereby making it more transparent and accessible to all. When this processes are improve , it will impact the community positively.
Feasibility Note: The proposer already actively participates in the Cardano community. There are details about the experience of the proposer and his skills, signalling the qualification and aptitude to execute the proposal. The Information Provided shows it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successful . The Budget items shows clearly what the money will be use for . There is comprehensive roadmap though no start date , I still score 5
Auditability Note: The proposal is very thorough. The url provided has substantial content. The road map and the budget is straight forward. I like the weekly breakdown. I believe this is sufficient to audit the progress and success of this proposal. Since there is no definition of a start date , i score 4

Impact / Alignment Note:
Trying to make sense of Catalyst is an almost impossible task with multiple channels and resources available (especially for newbies). As a Catalysts participant for several months i have seen Swarm starting to establish into a dependable hub. As such this proposal will help add value to the community and is worth funding. 

The piece i would have liked to have seen in this proposal is how the GitHub and Swarm aligns with the catalyst circle, IOG you tube channel and the catalyst community site (dev.projectcatalyst.org) along with others. There is some duplication of content (eg TH slides). As part of the marketing it would be good to how Swarm differentiates itself and the boundaries within which it works.
Feasibility Note:
I have validated the time estimates for maintenance and marketing with someone who does this for a living and they both make sense. 
As Stephen has been doing the maintenance it is reasonable to expect he will continue. 
The budget also seems sensible for this type of work. My reference point for this employment of freelance staff to conduct both admin and social media marketing roles on project i have run.
Auditability Note:
A set of targets to define success is missing. 
eg. 
- x link through from social media to gitbook 
- no of visits to gitbook 
- no of new attendees to swarm sessions - referred via the marketing campaign 

the risks should also be called out. There are 2 i see that require mitigation: 
1. Stephen is no longer able to maintain the gitbook or drive the social media updates 
2. sponsorship is not forthcoming in the next few months - do this work stop or will the proposer come back for further interim funding?

Impact / Alignment Note: It's important for a good decision making process to have a clear documentation and summary of everything, so this project will indeed be beneficial.
Feasibility Note: The work ist already being done, so it's succesful continuation is most likely. The hourly rate is a bit high for a documentation job and could maybe be set lower.
Auditability Note: It's easy to see whether the project is continued. It might be easier to audit if also certain quality criteria are set.

Impact / Alignment Note:
We really need a section for "additional funding" for previously funded proposals. Even though I completely understand why the proposer requires additional funding, it is not related to the challenge DIRECTLY. 

Anyway, the idea of such a working site is definitely with the alignment of the challenge, this proposal is asking for covering the maintenance.
Feasibility Note: they can deliver the product, cause it is running.
Auditability Note:
marketing + maintenance records. Can be audited. 

Success = already running...so....what to measure.

Impact / Alignment Note:
having an independent oversight for a project is a good idea. It can help with many things, with controlling the content - approve, decline - etc. Afterward, it can help the community to have filtered and relevant information. 

Also, there are more proposals which are addressing the previous proposal, rather than the challenge, therefore, it would be nice to have another special :fund: where you can increase the budget for the previous proposals, due to the growth, or changes which increase extra work. 

From this perspective, this proposal is NOT addressing the fund challenge, because it is addressing another proposal that addressed the challenge effectively in the previous fund, so this one is addressing it indirectly. Therefore I put a lower score.
Feasibility Note: approved. Also a very detailed schedule was provided (even tough there is no way how to control it, it feels real)
Auditability Note: time spent on the git book is stated. I do not find it as sufficient, maybe records on approved/declined/viewed posts would also be nice (if this is automatically traceable, and considered as a standard, then I would put 5)

Impact / Alignment Note:
A useful proposal, to sustain and fund important work that is already being done. Having somewhere that newcomers can find a record of Swarm activities, meetings etc, helps with meaningful onboarding, as it directly addresses the challenge question about how newcomers find out about Catalyst. It also reassures newcomers about accountability and set standards for transparency; these things have a quiet but significant impact on building Catalyst's culture, and enabling people to contribute. 
It is also positive that the proposal includes ideas for sustaining itself beyond this funding round.
Feasibility Note: The work is already being done successfully, so there is little doubt that it can continue to be implemented successfully. The budget is clear and realistic, and the roadmap makes sense. The only new thing being done with the funding is addressing marketing and publicity; this is clearly feasible within the budget and timescale, although it would be good to have a bit more detail on specific marketing plans. For example, which social media accounts will be used, who do they reach, and how will posts be targeted towards newcomers so as to address key elements of the challenge setting?
Auditability Note: There is essentially enough information to audit success - the bulk of the work is auditable via looking at the gitbook itself. But auditability info on marketing could be improved a little. I would have liked to see the proposal establish what metrics it plans to look at to assess marketing success – will it be number of engagements on social media platforms/Discord etc, or will it be how far those engagements actually drive people to the gitbook? - and perhaps to set some broad marketing targets.

Impact / Alignment Note: Fits the brief, has the potential to improve community confidence and answers positively "Did we get better at distributed decision making?" Helps group decision making be accessible to newcomers. Ensures the Catalyst process keeps iterating to improve.
Feasibility Note: The proposer is qualified to bring the project to success, having already demonstrated this ability with existing documentation. The budget is reasonable, and covers two rounds of funding.
Auditability Note: The roadmap shows KPIs and the project is easily trackable and verifiable by visiting the GitBook.

Impact / Alignment Note:
As can be seen in other fields of catalyst, even though if information is publicly available it is not enough. Making the information accessible and easy to find, what one is looking for is a major factor to transparency. The proposer is already doing this on a voluntary basis at the moment and in my opinion, the provided links to his work are enough evidence of the value he adds. 

I fully agree that this work allows the community to make easier decisions by enabling them to get the information they are looking for. 

I rate this proposals impact at a 5 because I consider the service it will provide as essential to create widespread transparency about the catalyst circle, which is an important factor to all catalyst.
Feasibility Note:
Since the work that is proposed to be done is already ongoing, I consider it out of question that this proposal will be successfully implemented. Plenty of resources have been given to proof the capabilities of the proposer. 

The compensation asked at $40/h is fair for the UK area, so the work should also be sustainable from a monetary point of view. 

The biggest risk to implementation would be that the proposer can not continue his work because of unforeseen reasons. 

Since the mentioned risks are minimal, I give the feasibility of the proposal a rating of 5.
Auditability Note:
With the demonstration of current work done, a detailed break down of time consumption of the work and a clear roadmap, there is nothing missing that would make the auditability unclear. 

Progress of the implementation of the documentation of catalyst circle is easily measured by checking availability of most recent activity documentation on the gitbook. 

I see no hurdle in auditability of this proposal and accordingly rate it at 5.

Impact / Alignment Note: Overall, this seems like an excellent, simple solution to the challenge of community participation and communication, as well as developing a community of committed leaders. Outsourcing and funding the administrative element of this role is generally scalable, however, you will likely have to keep adding resources if we want to truly impact the community on a global scale. This is still however, a good starting point. Any voter who understands the challenges and the whole point of the Catalyst Circle should be able to see the value in this and be able to vote effectively on it. In terms of value to the fund, effectively outsourcing the admin and social outreach/marketing, should be good value as specialists (as opposed to volunteers) will be paid to deliver, thus making the whole thing more efficient and slick.
Feasibility Note: Broadly, the proposer appears to know what they are doing and I believe that they will be able to set this up. However, the funding and time commitment (especially for the marketing/social media part) seems insufficient. 4 hours a month (or an hour a week) seems as though it would be the bare minimum. It would cover the "communication" part of the proposal but not the "promotion" or "engagement". If we truly want it to create impact at scale, more hours and more thought will need to go into this part of the proposal. I say this as someone who has been marketing for over 10 years.
Auditability Note: The milestones and KPI's are clearly well defined. They seem very transparent however, there are no identified risks or challenges. This could be because there aren't any obvious ones but it would be good to see this considered in the proposal - as a qualified project manager (Agile), I would suggest there are always going to be some risks and challenges!

Impact / Alignment Note:
Auditing and governance are very much alike - hard to motivate when its there and things go right but missed when things go wrong and also it is keeping things within parameters of stability. 
if you don't have some form of objective checks, you can operate on a cliff edge and not even realise it. 
So the function is important. Having too many checks can be counterproductive - and it is usually because the processes are not continuously reviewed objectively. 
Therefore as the recording/record keeping is very operational and administratively tedious and time consuming - its definitely necessary to manage that cliff edge risk.
Feasibility Note:
I do see that a next round of funding will help to establish this needed function more. 
Maybe I've missed it, but I would like to see more metrics/kpi's and trendlines against Circle's e.g. "consitutional/guiding principles" or the four major goals: 
1) To facilitate communication between the different functional groups 
2) To provide a heads-up when red lines are crossed within a certain group 
3) To suggest improvements on plans and processes that shape Project Catalyst 
4) To define the election process for Circle V2 
Maybe this can even start off to be soft evalaution and be done against member sentiment or a quick town hall or swarm vote/poll. 

Although this is limited to fund 6 - I do agree that this is also be included in fund 7
Auditability Note:
the momentum is there, the need is there and it seems as if the detail is there - but I do miss more definition on what documentation and tracking is going live. 
Also this roll out to be accompanied by some dashboard/Traffic light tracker with e.g. RAG status against this defined documentation and tracking .

Impact / Alignment Note: This proposal effectively addresses the challenge. The goal of onboarding more people into catalyst is a necessary step to its success. The amount of information that is created weekly requires a clear and common place which can be accessed by all users. Having the Gitbook will serve as a key place for new comers to catalyst and will also be invaluable as catalyst grows to new heights. The ability to track our growth in a way that is accessible will be pivotal to continued growth.
Feasibility Note:
Given the experience and plan presented it is extremely likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully. Stephen has been a key player in the catalyst swarm sessions and has been providing much of his time for free to date. His participation in the swarm meetings and the follow up work behind the scenes is a testament to his willingness to continue this work on his own. The plan presented is clear, well laid out, and shows that a lot of thought has already gone into this. The links provided by the proposer also strengthen it overall by providing additional information, however the proposal itself is strong as a stand alone for voters who may not have the time/will to look at all the links. 
In addition, the budget being requested seems more than fair for this work and doesn't capture free work he has already put in.
Auditability Note: The reason I am not giving this criteria a 5 is because I would like to see more information at each of the milestones. For example, the proposer highlights that sustainability is a key component of this work and that sponsorships are being sought, but I think more information could be provided here. What type of sponsorships? Would the idea to have others eventually do the Gitbook? There is also no real contingency should something happen to the one proposer. If say he gets sick, or something happens that pulls him away, what will happen? While I do think the proposal does allow for auditing the progress and success, some additional thinking on the points raised here will strengthen the possibility of overall success. Still, great work and looking forward to the outcome.
